notesStmt.note: The manuscript was sold in 1692/1693 for the price of 1000 akçe. On folio 3r we find Boris Kokenaj’s signature in Arabic script. Located in the margins throughout the manuscript we find linguistic remarks written in pencil by Józef Sulimowicz (1913–1973), who made a note of some of the more interesting word forms. The Book of Ruth was critically edited by Németh (2015).

msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Former Prophets, the Book of Ruth, the Book of Esther, and some passages of the Book of Proverbs

supportDesc.condition: Good, the text is clearly legible, the item underwent a complex restoration treatment in 2013, see Pronobis-Gajdzis (2014).

layout.p: Written in one column with 25 lines per page

scriptNote.p: Script type: Yevano Karaitic mashait script
Diacritics: Dagesh, sin dot, shin dot, and mappiq not used. Raphe used for marking spirantization.

Characteristic features of the script: The structure of the letter aleph stands between the K-structure and the N-structure: the vertical left stroke almost always joins the top of the middle stroke, and the right stroke is very small and joins the middle stroke halfway. The letter daleth resembles resh but the corner of the daleth is an acute angle, whereas the corner of resh is curved. The letter gimel resembles nun but the upper stroke of the letter tends to be vertical, and the corner of the gimel is an acute angle. The left and right stroke of the letter teth are of the same hight. The letter lamedh has a two-stroke structure; the upper stroke is straight, the horizontal middle stroke is missing. The final mem is circular, but the stroke ends outside the letter with a downward movement. The corner of nun is rounded; the final nun has the shape of a straight vertical line. No final pe form is used. The inner stroke of the letter shin is usually joined to the middle of the left stroke. In the final words of a line, individual letter forms are occasionally elongated to ensure full justification of the column. The script strongly resembles the one presented in plate 392 of Birnbaum, Salomo A. 1954–1957. The Hebrew Scripts. Part Two: The Plates. London.
